text: Nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) / Rel proteins are inducible transcriptional regulators of numerous cellular genes .
They are particularly abundant in lymphoid tissues and are thought to be critical for the transcription of genes involved in immune and inflammatory responses .
We have reported previously that a nuclear NF-kappa B activity was present in freshly extracted human thymocytes in the absence of in vitro treatment of these cells .

In the present report , we identified NF-kappa B proteins extracted from human thymocyte nuclei as being <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complexes .
Immunochemical and immunofluorescent staining of thymus sections using specific Abs allowed visualization of nuclear NF-kappa B proteins in both thymocytes and nonthymocyte cells .

This detection suggested a preferential activation of <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in medullary thymocytes , whereas <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was present in both cortical and medullary regions of human thymus lobules .

text: These observations suggest that <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complexes play distinct roles in gene expression and that both forms of NF-kappa B play critical roles during late stages of the intrathymic maturation of T cells .
